z:row.TitlePrimary: Top-quark spin correlation at linear colliders with anomalous couplings
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Acad Sinica, Inst High Energy Phys, Beijing 100039, Peoples R China. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Lin, ZH, Acad Sinica, Inst High Energy Phys, Beijing 100039, Peoples R China.
z:row.Abstract: We investigate the feasibility of probing anomalous top-quark couplings of Wtb, Zt (t) over bar, and gammat (t) over bar in terms of an effective Lagrangian with dimension-six operators at future e(+)e(-) linear colliders with a c.m. energy roots similar to500-800 GeV. We first examine the constraints on these anomalous couplings from the Z-->b (b) over bar data at CERN LEP I and from unitarity considerations. We then consider in detail the effects of anomalous couplings on t (t) over bar spin correlations in the top-pair production and decay with three spin bases: the helicity, beamline, and off-diagonal bases. Our results show that the polarized beams are more suitable for exploring the effects of different new operators. For polarized beams, the helicity basis yields the best sensitivity.

z:row.TitlePrimary: e(+)e(-)-> t(t)over-barH with nonstandard Higgs boson couplings
z:row.Keyword: FERMION MASS GENERATION|DYNAMIC SYMMETRY-BREAKING|STANDARD MODEL|3RD-FAMILY QUARKS|TOP QUARK|SCALE|UNITARITY|T(T)OVER-BAR|CONDENSATION|COLLIDERS|Astronomy & Astrophysics|Physics, Particles & Fields
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Acad Sinica, Inst High Energy Phys, Beijing 100039, Peoples R China. Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Theory Grp, Batavia, IL 60510 USA.; Han, T, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Phys, 1150 Univ Ave, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: We consider a general effective Lagrangian for couplings of a Higgs boson to the top quark to dimension-six operators including CP violation effects. Constraints on some of them an derived from the Z --> b (b) over bar data. We study the process e(+)e(-)--> t (t) over bar H to probe the nonstandard couplings. We find that at a linear collider with a c.m. energy root s similar to 0.5-1.5 TeV and a high luminosity of 10-1000 fb(-1), these non-standard couplings may be sensitively probed.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Determination of Linear Vibration Systems J-Matrix from Input-Output Data
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Modal Analysis-the International Journal of Analytical and Experimental Modal Analysis
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: ZHANG, PQ, UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH & ASTRONAT,MADISON,WI 53706.
z:row.Abstract: For a linear vibration system with repeated eigenvalues, its transfer function is not only determined by the system's modal parameters, but also by the number and order of the Jordan matrices corresponding to each repeated eigenvalue in the uncoupling of the system motion equation. The information about the repeated eigenvalues of the vibration system is further developed as the vibration system's new J-matrix. The J-matrix and the transfer function which involves the J-matrix are important in understanding the vibration system's dynamic properties. A method of determining the J-matrix of the linear vibration system from the system's input and output data is presented in the paper. Some examples are used to show the effectiveness of the method.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Online updating appearance generative mixture model for meanshift tracking
z:row.TitleSecondary: Computer Vision - ACCV 2006. 7th Asian Conference on Computer Vision. Proceedings, Part I, 13-16 Jan. 2006
z:row.TitleTertiary: Computer Vision - ACCV 2006. 7th Asian Conference on Computer Vision. Proceedings, Part I (Lecture Notes in Computer Science Vol. 3851)
z:row.Keyword: Bayes methods|computer vision|expectation-maximisation algorithm|image motion analysis|object recognition|tracking
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Elec. & Comp. Engr., Illinois Univ., Urbana, IL, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper proposes an appearance generative mixture model based on key frames for meanshift tracking. Meanshift tracking algorithm tracks object by maximizing the similarity between the histogram in tracking window and a static histogram acquired at the beginning of tracking. The tracking therefore may fail if the appearance of the object varies substantially. Assume the key appearances of the object can be acquired before tracking, the manifold of the object appearance can be approximated by some piece-wise linear combination of these key appearances in histogram space. The generative process can be described by a Bayesian graphical model. Online EM algorithm is then derived to estimate the model parameters and to update the appearance histogram. The updating histogram would improve meanshift tracking accuracy and reliability, and the model parameters infer the state of the object with respect to the key appearances. We applied this approach to track human head motion and to infer the head pose simultaneously in videos. Experiments verify that, our online histogram generative updating algorithm constrained by key appearance histograms avoids the drifting problem often encountered in tracking with online updating, that the enhanced meanshift algorithm is capable of tracking object of varying appearances more robustly and accurately, and that our tracking algorithm can infer the state of the object (e.g., pose) simultaneously as a bonus
z:row.User2: appearance generative mixture model; meanshift tracking; object tracking; histogram similarity maximization; tracking window; static histogram; object appearance; piecewise linear combination; histogram space; Bayesian graphical model; expectation-maximization algorithm; human head motion tracking; head pose

z:row.TitlePrimary: Affective multimodal human-computer interaction
z:row.TitleSecondary: 13th Annual ACM International Conference on Multimedia, 6-11 Nov. 2005
z:row.TitleTertiary: 13th Annual ACM International Conference on Multimedia
z:row.Keyword: human computer interaction|social aspects of automation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fac. of EEMCS, Delft Univ. of Technol., Netherlands
z:row.Abstract: Social and emotional intelligence are aspects of human intelligence that have been argued to be better predictors than IQ for measuring aspects of success in life, especially in social interactions, learning, and adapting to what is important. When it comes to machines, not all of them needs such skills. Yet to have machines like computers, broadcast systems, and cars, capable of adapting to their users and of anticipating their wishes, endowing them with the ability to recognize user's affective states is necessary. This article discusses the components of human affect, how they might be integrated into computers, and how far are we from realizing affective multimodal human-computer interaction
z:row.User2: multimodal human-computer interaction; social intelligence; emotional intelligence; human intelligence; social interaction

z:row.TitlePrimary: Generative and discriminative face modelling for detection
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings Fifth IEEE International Conference on Automatic Face Gesture Recognition, 20-21 May 2002
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of Fifth IEEE International Conference on Automatic Face Gesture Recognition
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Beckman Inst. for Adv. Sci. & Technol., Illinois Univ., Urbana, IL, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper reports a new image model combining self mutual information based generative modelling and fisher discriminant based discriminative modelling. Past work on face modelling have focused heavily on either generative modelling or boundary modelling considering negative examples. The motivation of this work is to examine the combinational treatment and study its effect. To effectively learn the model's parameters, a tree structure is employed to describe the inter-pixel relationships, both due to the simplicity of the structure representation and the ease of parameter estimation through decoupling a full distribution into pair-wise distributions. To fit training data distribution more accurately, we use a non-parametric representation rather than a particular parametric family of distributions for entropy estimation. We explicate the model learning and demonstrate its effectiveness primarily through the problem of face detection, i.e. modelling the 2d image appearance of human face
z:row.User2: discriminative face modelling; generative face modelling; image model; self mutual information based generative modelling; fisher-discriminant based discriminative modelling; combinational treatment; tree structure; inter-pixel relationships; parameter estimation; pair-wise distributions; entropy estimation; face detection; 2d image appearance

z:row.TitlePrimary: e+e-→tt¯H with nonstandard Higgs boson couplings
z:row.TitleTertiary: Phys. Rev. D (USA)
z:row.Keyword: CP invariance|electron-positron interactions|hadron electroproduction|Higgs bosons|intermediate boson production
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: We consider a general effective Lagrangian for couplings of a Higgs boson to the top quark to dimension-six operators including CP violation effects. Constraints on some of them are derived from the Z→bb¯ data. We study the process e+e-→tt¯H to probe the nonstandard couplings. We find that at a linear collider with a c.m. energy √5~0.5-1.5 TeV and a high luminosity of 10-1000 fb-1, these non-standard couplings may be sensitively probed
z:row.User2: nonstandard Higgs boson couplings; effective Lagrangian; dimension-six operators; CP violation effects; nonstandard couplings; positron+electron producing antitop+top+Higgs

z:row.Abstract: In this paper, we analyze the dynamical behavior of the linear wave equation on an interval, where the right endpoint has a van der Pol type nonlinearity or boundary controller, while the left endpoint has a boundary condition involving displacement. The asymptotic behavior of the system can be classified into two basic types: classical unbounded instability, or spatial point-wise convergence to periodic points of a nonlinear map corresponding to the van der Pol condition.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Determination of linear vibration system's J-matrix from input-output data
z:row.Keyword: Systems analysis|Vibrations (mechanical)|Matrix algebra|Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions|Controllability|Observability|Degrees of freedom (mechanics)|Equations of motion|Transfer functions|Numerical analysis

z:row.Publisher: Publ by Virginia Polytechnic Inst, Blacksburg, VA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: For a linear vibration system with repeated eigenvalues, its transfer function is not only determined by the system's modal parameters, but also by the number and order of the Jordan matrices corresponding to each repeated eigenvalue in the uncoupling of the system motion equation. The information about the repeated eigenvalues of the vibration system is further developed as the vibration system's new J-matrix. The J-matrix and the transfer function which involves the J-matrix are important in understanding the vibration system's dynamic properties. A method of determining the J-matrix of the linear vibration system from the system's input and output data is presented in the paper. Some examples are used to show the effectiveness of the method.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Linear vibration systems; Jordan matrices; Experimental modal analysis; Input output data

z:row.TitlePrimary: Vibration analysis of a miniature silicon resonating beam force sensor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 11th International Modal Analysis Conference, Feb 1-4 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
z:row.Keyword: Vibrations (mechanical)|Force measurement|Silicon sensors|Miniature instruments|Structural analysis|Dynamic response|Resonance|Damping|Frequency response|Parameter estimation|Sensitivity analysis|Time domain analysis|Mathematical models
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers, Bellingham, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, new experimental dynamic measurement techniques, such as Pulse-Electric-Spark excitation technique and Working Point-Locking Michelson Interferometer, are used to analyze the dynamic properties of a miniature silicon resonating beam (3 mm×0.4 mm) force sensor that is a representative of microelectromechanical system. Theoretical dynamic analysis of component beams is also performed. By means of the modal parameter identification techniques of the time domain by laser measurement data, the modal parameters are calculated. Furthermore, the thickness of the resonating beam and the mass and the rotational mass moment of inertia of the force-imposed ring part of the sensor are determined by equating the results from experiments and theoretical analysis. Particular attention is given to the results of mode shapes, damping factors and relative sensitivity of the resonance frequencies as a function of force acted on the sensor beam, that provides a scientific basis for the optimum design of a resonant beam force sensor of this kind. The results presented in this paper show that the experimental techniques - having high sensitivity, broad frequency response and expected accuracy - are an effective method for investigating the dynamic properties of microstructures.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Miniature silicon resonating beam force sensor; Working point locking Michelson interferometers; Pulse electric spark excitation technique; Microelectromechanical systems; Modal parameter estimation; Resonance frequencies; Relative sensitivity; Damping factors; Mode shapes

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental modal analysis of miniature objects by optical measurement technique
z:row.Keyword: Vibrations (mechanical)|Structural analysis|Dynamic response|Correlation methods|Time domain analysis|Frequency domain analysis|Optics|Beams and girders
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal of Analytical and Experimental Modal Analysis
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison
z:row.Abstract: In this paper, we analyze theoretically the use of correlation statistical properties in the random speckle field, in the non-contact recording of free-response information of vibrating objects, and in terms of time-domain signals collected simultaneously at multiple points, and we use system identification techniques in the frequency and time domains to identify the dynamic parameters. The bending vibration of a miniature cantilever beam and the torsional vibration of a miniature shaft with 3-degrees of freedom are measured. The dynamic property parameters identified are in good agreement with the theoretical values. By the same process, the lower-order natural frequencies and modes of the bending arm of a dental drill are measured and analyzed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Miniature objects; Random speckle field; System identification techniques; Dynamic parameters; Noncontact recording; Dental drill

The results of natural or damped natural frequencies, damping factors and scaled modes both for the in-plane case and the case normal to the plane have been tabulated, plotted and compared. The comparisons are then discussed.

When the slotted shell is compared with the original perfect shell, it is found that several new mode vectors are created for the slotted shell, and the characteristics of the kept modes. z:row.Abstract: The results are exact solutions that can be obtained without resorting to numerical or iteration schemes. In the analysis, the position of a link in a mechanism is fully defined if its direction and length are known. Therefore, this analysis involves the calculation of the unknown direction cosines and length of each link for a given configuration of the mechanism. In finding the direction cosines of the unknown unit vectors involved for each link and rotating axis, two types of coordinates, the global and the local, are generally used. Then, a direction cosine matrix between each local coordinate system and the global coordinates is established. Thus, the unknown direction cosines of the local coordinates, the links, and the rotating axes are obtained in global coordinates. As an illustration, the application of this method to the study of four-link spatial mechanisms, RGGR, RGCR, RRGG, and RRGC is presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: DIRECTION COSINE; SPATIAL LINKAGE

z:row.TitlePrimary: DYNAMIC INSTABILITY OF LIQUID FREE SURFACE IN A CONTAINER WITH ELASTIC BOTTOM UNDER COMBINED HARMONIC AND STOCHASTIC LONGITUDINAL EXCITATION
z:row.TitleSecondary: Random Vibrations. Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
z:row.TitleTertiary: AMD (Symposia Series) (American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Applied Mechanics Division)
z:row.Keyword: FLUID MECHANICS -- Analysis|PROBABILITY - Random Processes|FLUID DYNAMICS - Analysis|MATERIALS TESTING|VIBRATIONS - Analysis|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Differential Equations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The coupling between the liquid surface and the elastic tank bottom is studied. It is found that the variation of the frequency and the stability of the liquid free surface due to the coupling depend on the ratio of the liquid height to the tank transverse dimension. The unstable region of the liquid surface due to harmonically parametric excitation may be narrowed by the coupling under certain conditions, while at the same time new unstable regions covering both subharmonic resonance and combination resonance of a differential type occur. In the case of a very low ratio of liquid height to tank transverse dimension, all unstable regions may be very wide. Damping narrows the width of the unstable region of subharmonic resonance, but it can widen the unstable region of combination resonance. The coupled system is always destabilized by the stochastic component of parametric excitation, and it is always unstable without damping.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: COUPLING; DAMPING; WHITE NOISE EXCITATION; LONGITUDINAL EXCITATION; HARMONIC AND STOCHASTIC EXCITATION

z:row.Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 15 papers. Some of the topics discussed are: use of time transformation methods in fatigue and fatigue crack growth; response of non-linear oscillators to stochastic excitation; probabilistic structural dynamics of an inelastic structural system; stability and response of a randomly excited hanging string in fluid; wide band random vibration of an equilateral triangular plate; probabilistic factors; experimental design, and statistical and variance analysis for fatigue under random vibrations; oscillator response to non-stationary excitation; orthogonal decomposition and transmission of nonstationary random processes; dynamic instability of liquid free surface in a container with elastic bottom under combined harmonic and stochastic longitudinal excitation.

z:row.TitlePrimary: STABILITY AND RESPONSE OF A RANDOMLY EXCITED HANGING STRING IN FLUID
z:row.TitleSecondary: Random Vibrations. Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
z:row.TitleTertiary: AMD (Symposia Series) (American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Applied Mechanics Division)
z:row.Keyword: VIBRATIONS -- Analysis|FLUID MECHANICS - Analysis|PROBABILITY - Random Processes|NOISE, SPURIOUS SIGNAL - Spectrum Analysis|OCEAN ENGINEERING - Applications
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper discusses the parametrically excited vibration of a hanging string in fluid. The straight and vertical configuration of the string may become unstable when the suspension point of the heavy string moves up and down randomly under certain conditions. In the first part of the paper, the stability conditions and the transition probability density function of the amplitudes of various orders are obtained under the assumption of linear damping. In the second part, the response of the string to random parametrical excitation is discussed, under the assumption that the damping is nonlinear. The analytical expression of the stationary state probability density function and the Nth moment of amplitude are also obtained. The results show that nonlinear damping plays an important role in limiting the growth of amplitude.

z:row.User2: LINEAR DAMPING; PARAMETRICAL EXCITATION; NONLINEAR DAMPING; HANGING STRING IN FLUID; SUSPENSION POINT

z:row.TitleSecondary: Random Vibrations. Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
z:row.TitleTertiary: AMD (Symposia Series) (American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Applied Mechanics Division)
z:row.Keyword: VIBRATIONS -- Analysis|MATERIALS TESTING - Fatigue|STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS - Dynamic Response|PROBABILITY - Random Processes|STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Vibrations|FATIGUE OF MATERIALS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper deals with the deterministic and probabilistic factors that affect the fatigue life of materials. It also describes the experimental design techniques that are applied to determine fatigue life experimentally under the influence of multiple factors as well as the statistical and variance analyses that are used both to ascertain the validity of the fatigue life predicting equations and to establish the confidence intervals of the prediction. Because this new approach applies well to fatigue under multiple deterministic factors, narrow band random vibrations, and broad band random vibrations, it should be developed further into practical use.

z:row.User2: FATIGUE LIFE; RANDOM LOADINGS; CUMULATIVE DAMAGE; PARAMETRIC STUDY; PHENOMENOLOGICAL APPROACH

z:row.TitlePrimary: ELASTIC SYSTEM MOVING ON AN ELASTICALLY SUPPORTED BEAM
z:row.Keyword: VEHICLES|STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS - Dynamic Response|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vibration, Acoustics, Stress, and Reliability in Design
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Engineering Mechanics, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: The moving elastic system or vehicle is represented by the structural members with distributed stiffness, damping, and inertia properties, and it is supported by the suspension units. Each suspension unit consists of a linear spring, a viscous damper, and an unsprung mass. The beam is supported at discrete points along its length, and/or by an elastic foundation. The deformations of the moving system and the beam are represented by their corresponding eigenfunction series. The resulting governing equations are represented by the coupled, ordinary differential equations with variable coefficients. The equations of motion for an elastic platform moving with constant velocity on a beam are derived and solved by the Hamming's predictor-corrector method. Numerical examples are presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.Abstract: The effects of random environmental torques and noise on the moments of inertia of spinning and three-axes stabilized satellites can be investigated by various methods. In two previous papers, four analytical methods were used. The present paper evaluates the results obtained from analog simulation. A comparison is made between analog simulation and the predictions of the four analytical methods. Comparisons based on analytical grounds are also made among those analytical methods.

z:row.TitlePrimary: SINGULAR PERTURBATION EQUATIONS FOR FLEXIBLE SATELLITES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: Force equations of motion of the individual flexible elements of a satellite were obtained in a previous paper. Moment equations of motion of the composite bodies of the same satellite are developed in this paper. These two sets of equations form the basic system for any dynamic model of flexible satellites. These two sets of equations form the basic system for any dynamic model of flexible satellites. This basic system consists of a set of N-coupled, nonlinear, ordinary, or partial differential equations, for a flexible satellite with n generalized, structural position coordinates. For single composite body satellites, N is equal to (n plus 3). For dual-spin systems, N is equal to (n plus 9). These equations usually involve time derivatives up to the second order. For large values of n, linearization of the system has so far been the only practicable way of solution. The present study shows a method of avoiding this linearization by reducing the N equations to 3 or 9 non-linear, coupled, first order, ordinary, differential equations involving only the angular velocities of the composite bodies.

z:row.Abstract: A large class of vibration problems falls into the category of nonlinearly supported complex structures. A modal-perturbation technique is presented for the harmonic analysis of such systems. A particular example which arises in the landing of aircraft is used for illustration

z:row.TitlePrimary: An investigation of fatigue failure of materials under broad band random vibrations
z:row.TitleTertiary: AIAA J. (USA)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The fatigue life of material under the multifactor influence of broad band random excitations was investigated. Parameters which affect the fatigue life were postulated to be peak stress, variance of stress and the natural frequency of the system. Experimental data were processed by the hybrid computer. Based on the experimental results and the regression analysis, a best predicting model has been found. All values of the experimental fatigue lives are within the 95% confidence intervals of the predicing equation. Research results in narrow band random fatigue have been reported
z:row.User2: fatigue failure; broad band random vibrations; broad band random excitations; peak stress; variance of stress; natural frequency; hybrid computer

z:row.TitlePrimary: Free vibrations of viscoelastic Timoshenko beams
z:row.TitleTertiary: Trans. ASME, E, J. Appl. Mech. (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: Transactions of the ASME.Series E, Journal of Applied Mechanics
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The correspondence principle has been applied to derive the differential equations of viscoelastic Timoshenko beams with external viscous damping. These equations are solved by Laplace transform and boundary conditions are applied to obtain complex frequency equations and mode shapes for beams of any combination of end conditions. For beams without external damping, the correspondence principle can be applied directly to the available solutions of elastic Timoshenko beams. Numerical illustration is given

z:row.Abstract: To facilitate application of Timoshenko equations, report provides tables of eigenfunctions for solution to beam vibration problems; tables cover hinged-hinged, clamped-clamped, free-free, clamped-free, clamped-hinged and hinged-free beams; values are useful in studying forced vibrations and as limiting cases in analysis of damped flexural vibrations of beams.
